algorithm_technique: Iterate through possible quantities of one item, calculate remaining budget for the other, and sum up possibilities. Uses arithmetic progression sums.
Iterate through possible quantities of one item, calculate remaining budget for the other, and sum up possibilities.
problem_summary_simple: Find how many ways you can buy pens and pencils given their costs and a total budget.
problem_summary_technical: Iterate through the number of one item, calculate how many of the other can be bought with remaining budget, and sum up.
key_insights: The problem can be solved by iterating through the number of one item and calculating the possibilities for the other.
The number of ways to buy the second item forms an arithmetic progression for each fixed quantity of the first item.
Optimizing the iteration range and using arithmetic progression sum formula improves efficiency.
A straightforward approach is to iterate through all possible counts of one item (e.g., pens).
For each count of pens, calculate the maximum number of pencils that can be bought with the remaining money.
Summing up the counts of pencils for each pen count gives the total number of ways.
